coredata.dc:title: Regulating lithium-ion flux in the solid electrolyte interphase layer to prevent lithium dendrite growth on lithium metal anode
coredata.dc:creator: Ghanbarzadeh, Behnam
Khatibi, Ali
Asadi, Amir
Shokri, Babak
coredata.dc:description: High theoretical capacity and lowest electrochemical potential make lithium metal anode the most suitable anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, Lithium dendrite growth on lithium metal anode hinders proper discharge capacity and practical cycle life of LIBs. It dues to high lithium-ion flux in the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer versus low diffusion in anode structure. Herein, we employ argon and oxygen plasma to modify commercial polypropylene separator surface to negatively functionalize the separator surface and discuss the influence of increasing surface negative charge on lithium dendrite growth and formation of SEI layer. Comparing electrochemical and battery performance of unmodified and plasma modified separators demonstrates, increased negative surface charge prevents lithium dendrite growth and makes a uniform and thin SEI layer due to lowering lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer. More precisely, we conduct that coulombic interaction between plasma modified separator's surface and electrolyte's cations (anions) can regulate lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer, preventing lithium dendrite growth and making thin homogeneous SEI layer on lithium metal anode structure.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Lithium-ion battery
Separator
Plasma modification
Lithium dendrite
SEI layer

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) battery cell with plasma modified separator (b,c) OES spectra of argon and oxygen plasma at 20 w plasma power.
Tensile strength profiles of unmodified and (a) argon plasma modified and (b) oxygen plasma modified separators at different plasma modification times (1,3,10 min).
FE-SEM of (a) unmodified, (b) argon, and (c) oxygen plasma modified, and AFM images (d) unmodified, (e) argon, and (f) oxygen plasma modified separators at 1 min exposure time, respectively.

(a) ATR-FTIR and (b) XPS wide scan spectra of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators and deconvoluted c1s,o1s curves for (c and f) unmodified, (d and g) argon, and (h and e) oxygen plasma modified separators.
Contact angle of distilled water and electrolyte for (a) oxygen and (b) argon plasma modified separators at different modification times (unmodified, 1, 3, 5, 10 min).

(a) Surface zeta potential of unmodified, argon and oxygen plasma modified sample in 4 ramps(PH=6) (b) LSV curves of unmodified, argon and oxygen plasma modified separators (Li/separator+electrolyte/stainless steel,3 mV/s 3.5–6, V). (c) EIS curves of unmodified argon and oxygen plasma modified separators(stainless steel/separator+electrolyte/stainless steel,frequency range 100mHz-100KHz).

(a) Coulombic efficiency profiles of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators in 50 charge-discharge cycles at 1C .(b) Coulombic efficiency profiles of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators in different c-rates(0.1,0.2,0.5,1,2 C). (c) Discharge capacity profiles of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators in 50 cycles at 0.1C.(d) Discharge capacity profiles of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators in different c- rates(0.1,0.2,0.5,1,2 C).
Mechanism of lithium dendrite growth and SEI layer formation in battery cell structure. (a) with unmodified separator and (b) with plasma modified separator.
elemental composition and surface properties of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators.
Measured porosity and electrolyte uptake results for argon and oxygen plasma modified separators at different modification times(unmodified,1,3,5,10 min).

head.ce:title: Regulating lithium-ion flux in the solid electrolyte interphase layer to prevent lithium dendrite growth on lithium metal anode

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Laser and Plasma Research Institute, Shahid Beheshti University, Evin, Tehran 1983963113, Iran
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: aLaser and Plasma Research Institute, Shahid Beheshti University, Evin, Tehran 1983963113, Iran

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Physics Department, Shahid Beheshti University, Evin, Tehran 1983963113, Iran
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: bPhysics Department, Shahid Beheshti University, Evin, Tehran 1983963113, Iran

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: High theoretical capacity and lowest electrochemical potential make lithium metal anode the most suitable anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, Lithium dendrite growth on lithium metal anode hinders proper discharge capacity and practical cycle life of LIBs. It dues to high lithium-ion flux in the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer versus low diffusion in anode structure. Herein, we employ argon and oxygen plasma to modify commercial polypropylene separator surface to negatively functionalize the separator surface and discuss the influence of increasing surface negative charge on lithium dendrite growth and formation of SEI layer. Comparing electrochemical and battery performance of unmodified and plasma modified separators demonstrates, increased negative surface charge prevents lithium dendrite growth and makes a uniform and thin SEI layer due to lowering lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer. More precisely, we conduct that coulombic interaction between plasma modified separator's surface and electrolyte's cations (anions) can regulate lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer, preventing lithium dendrite growth and making thin homogeneous SEI layer on lithium metal anode structure.

ce:section.ce:para: Today, research on lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) plays a vital role in developing our technologies in many areas, including transportation, energy storage systems, communications, and lighting [1]. These batteries show a great promise of becoming the safe and reliable energy storage source for our future. The next generation of LIBs must have a high capacity, safety, and long cycle life [2]. Recently study on lithium metal anode (LiMA) base batteries takes more attention as a promising candidate for next-generation LIBs [3–6]. LiMA is an essential part of Li-Sulfur and Li-air battery structure as next-generation batteries [5,7]. Compared to other anode materials, LiMA has a high specific capacity (3860 mAh.g−1), the lowest electrochemical potential (−3.04 V versus standard hydrogen electrode), and low density (0.534 g.cm−3) [8–11]. Besides many advantages, the undesired growth of lithium dendrites in the lithium-ion deposition process on the LiMA hinders suitable cycle life and high discharge capacity for LiMA based batteries. High lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer versus low lithium-ion diffusion in LiMA structure accumulates lithium ions in the SEI-LiMA interface and lithium dendrite growth [3,8,9,12–14]. Lithium dendrite growth cracks weak SEI layer and increases internal impedance due to forming more SEI layer by self-healing reaction between electrolyte and LiMA. Self-healing reaction between LiMA and electrolyte drains the electrolyte and causes cell malfunction [10,12,15,16]. Lithium dendrite growth makes an inhomogeneous and insulated SEI layer that prevents lithium-ion's reversibility in the charge-discharge cycle by disrupting the electrical field's uniformity in the LiMA structure [16]. The formation of the lithium dendrites decreases the lithium metal-based batteries' life in two ways, first by piercing the separator and second by increasing the battery's internal resistance due to significant growth of the SEI layer [12,16]. Ionic mobility and diffusivity in the electrolyte directly affect lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer. As a result, it affects the SEI layer's homogeneity and thickness by preventing lithium dendrite growth. From Einstein relation, the mobility and diffusivity of cations and anions (Li+, PF6 −) in the electrolyte are affected by the van der Waals and Coulombic collisions of anions, cations, and other species inside the electrolyte [17–19]. The separator is a component of LIBs directly exposed to the electrolyte, so the separator's surface chemical composition affects the diffusivity and mobility of lithium-ions in electrolyte [19]. By changing the separator's chemical composition, the lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer can be controlled, and as a result, lithium dendrite growth will be prevented [12]. The separator is a porous membrane placed between the electrodes that prevents physical contact of electrodes and short circuit while allowing the permeation of lithium ions within the electrolyte [20]. Many types of separators have been incorporated in past years, such as Polyolefin separators like Polyethylene (PE) or Polypropylene (PP), showing excellent chemical stability and mechanical strength. In recent years, research on polyolefin separators has been remarkably increased [20], however, their hydrophobic behavior due to low surface energy could still be a disadvantage. Research in the separator field is based on changing surface properties without altering the bulk structure. A wide variety of ways like Inorganic coatings, polymer coating, polymer grafting, and physical (chemical) vapor deposition have been employed to improve their shortcoming [12,17,21–25]. Coating, grafting, and deposition methods, despite altering the separator's surface chemistry, having a complicated process, and lowering ionic conductivity by blocking separator pores [24,26]. A reliable and simple method is plasma modification, which has proven to be an effective way to change polymers' surface chemistry. Its simple and environmentally friendly process induces uniform functional groups on the polymeric surfaces and does not change the bulk physical properties [27–30]. Recently it was reported that the surface negative functional group could affect the homogeneity and thickness of the SEI layer [22]. In this work, we employed plasma modification on the commercial PP separator to control lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer by inducing negative functional groups. We used argon and oxygen low-pressure plasma to investigate the influence of increasing negative surface charge on lithium-ion flux and prevention of lithium dendrites. The mechanical, physical, and chemical properties of plasma modified separators were investigated using tensile strength, FE-SEM and AFM, XPS, and ATR-FTIR analysis. For further analyzing surface change, contact angle, electrolyte uptake, and porosity analysis were also studied. Zeta potential analysis was used to investigate the type and amount of negative surface charge. We further used Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) and Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) analysis to study ionic conductivity and the influence of increasing negative surface charge on lithium dendrite growth. As a practical application, we investigated the battery performance of samples modified with argon and oxygen plasma along with LiMA for studying lithium dendrite formation in the charge-discharge cycle by coulombic efficiency and discharge capacity results.

Commercial PP Separator (Cellgard 2400, Celgard co, South Korea) with a thickness of 25 μm. 1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) was combined with ethylene carbonate (EC), and dimethyl carbonate (DMC), EC: DMC = 1:1, by volume, (Merck, Germany) was used as battery electrolyte. 1-butanol, with a purity of 99.8%, was purchased from Merck. Lithium metal foil with a thickness of 300 μm was purchased from MTI Co, China.

The plasma modification process was carried out in a stainless steel chamber with dimensions (D= 380 mm × 400 mm). A base pressure of 1 mTorr was achieved by utilizing a Double Stage Rotary Pump (D 60) and a WKP 500 Roots Vacuum Pump. Mass flow controllers maintained 20 Sccm gas flow rates into the vacuum chamber to achieve the desired working pressure (60–80 mTorr). The top electrode was grounded, and the bottom electrode was connected to a radio frequency (RF) power supply (Stolberg cito1312, Germany). Optimum power of 20 W was used for the plasma modification process.

Various kinds of species such as ionized atoms and molecules can emerge within the plasma volume. Optical Emission Spectroscopy (OES) was carried out (Avantes Avaspec, Netherlands) with a 0.6 nm spectral resolution to detect them. Tensile strength measurements were carried out by a micro tensile tester (Santam STM) instrument at room temperature to investigate the PP structure's mechanical strength before and after the plasma modification. The dimension of test samples was 3 × 2 cm, and the rate of stretch was 10 mm/min. The morphology and surface of PP separators were imaged by scanning electron microscopes (Hitachi s-4160, Japan). Atomic Force Microscopes (AFM) (Nanosurf Easyscan, Switzerland) were used to measure surface roughness due to the plasma modification process. Attenuated Total Reflectance Fourier Transform Infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy (Bruker, USA) with wavenumber range of 500–4000 cm−1 and resolution of 1 cm−1 were used to detect the chemical groups present in the PP sample and the plasma modification samples. To understand and detect the chemical changes of PP separators which are made by plasma, unmodified and modified separators were analyzed by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) (PHI Quantera II, USA) with using focused monochromatic Al Kα source (1486.6 eV) and 7.5–400 μm spot size. To study the changes of wettability, contact angle measurement by the sessile method with 2μL of distilled water and electrolyte (1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (EC: DMC = 1:1, by volume) were carried out in room temperature. PP samples were soaked in an electrolyte solution to measure the electrolyte uptake changes. The residual electrolyte on the surface was cleaned with filter paper. The weight of the separator was measured. The following equation calculates the electrolyte uptake: Electrolyte uptake = [(W – W0)/W0] × 100 in which W0 and W are the weight of the dry and wet samples, respectively. In order to determine the porosity of separators, each sample was immersed in a 1-butanol solution for 30 min. The following equation is used to calculate the results: Porosity = (mb/Pb)/ (ms/Ps+ ms/ Ps) × 100 where ms and mb are the mass and Ps and Pb are the density of separator and 1-butanol, respectively.

Zeta potential test was used to measure the surface charge of the PP separator (Electrokinetic Analyser Anton Paar, Austria). LSV of sample cells with the following composition, stainless steel/separator with electrolyte/Lithium metal, was performed at a scan rate of 3mv/s over the range of 3.5–6 V at room temperature (OrigaFlex OGFEIS, France). EIS over the range of 100 MHz to 100 kHz with an amplitude of 20 mV at 25 °C was used to measure the bulk resistance between stainless steel electrodes (OrigaFlex OGFEIS, France). Ionic conductivity (σ) of separators is calculated based on the σ=d/RA equation, where d is the thickness of the separator (25 μm), A (19 mm diameter) is an effective area of separator in coin cells, and R represents bulk resistance which comes from Nyquist plots. In order to perform battery performance testing, coin cells were prepared by sandwiching the PP separator along with the liquid electrolyte between the LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM) cathode and LiMA. To prepare the cathode layer, 80% NCM active material, 10% C65 Carbon black, 5% conductive graphite, and 5% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) as a binder in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) were mixed. Then the slurry was stirred for one h. The slurry was then coated on an aluminum foil current collector via blade coating method and dried at 90 °C for three hours. The resulting thickness of the coated layer was about 50 μm. The performance of the cells was tested in a CR-2032 coin cell. The cells were assembled and sealed in an argon-filled inert atmosphere glove box (H2O and O2 < 1 ppm). Room temperature charge/discharge analysis was performed to examine the performance of battery cells (Li /Separator with electrolyte/LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 saturated with LiPF6 electrolyte). Voltage was set from 2.5 V - 4.3 V and C rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2C. (Neware BTS4000)

OES was taken to characterize the reactive species, including ions and metastable states generated by the plasma. Fig. 1 a Indicates battery cell with a separator that was modified by plasma, and Fig. 1c and b shows OES spectra for argon and oxygen plasma, respectively. In Fig. 1b, characteristic peaks at 696.5–852.1 nm wavelength range correspond to Ar plasma (Ar+ species). In oxygen plasma, OES spectra unique peaks in 777.4, 844.6 nm wavelength correspond to monoatomic oxygen, and peaks at 559.1, 525.7, 598.83, 638, 677.42 nm wavelength are attributed to O2+, O+ ions [31].

The tensile strength of separators is an essential property because separators should have enough mechanical stability to withstand the stretching during the battery assembling, penetration due to the growth of lithium dendrites, and cyclic deformation of electrodes [32]. Longitudinal tensile measurements investigated unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators. The stress-strain curve of unmodified and plasma modified separators was shown in Fig. 2 a and b. Plasma modification reduces tensile strength caused by polymer chain scission depicts the tensile strength evolution of plasma modified separators in various modification times. The tensile strength of the unmodified separator was 129 MPa. However, the argon and oxygen plasma modified separator's tensile strength in different modification times (1, 3, 10 min) were 37, 33.3, 17.7 MPa, and 33.5, 24.2, 5.5 MPa, respectively. These results show that increasing plasma modification time reduces the tensile strength. In order to decrease this damage, 1 min plasma modified separators were selected, and they were used to characterize surface physical/chemical properties, electrochemical, and battery performance analysis.

FE-SEM and AFM analysis were taken from the samples before and after the plasma modification to study the morphology and structures of the separators. According to Fig. 3 b and c plasma modification has changed the separator's surface structure. This is due to the etching of reactive plasma species on the polymer's surface. Also, in Fig. 3, the FE-SEM image shows the features attributed to the plasma's effect on the separator's pores, marked with a yellow circle in the figure. Comparing the FE-SEM images shows the structure's porosity increases by the plasma modification for both argon and oxygen plasma modified separators. These effects can be advantageous in increasing surface energy and, as a result, the separator's electrolyte uptake and contact angle directly affect battery performance. For further analyzing the topographical and surface properties of separators, AFM images were taken. As shown in Fig. 3, we can see from the AFM images that the unmodified sample has a smooth surface. However, as illustrated in images 3. e,f for the samples modified with argon and oxygen plasma, some annular protrusions feature formed on the separators' surface. Annular protrusions made the surface rougher and could lead to high electrolyte uptake and contact angle due to increasing contact area between the indented separator surface and electrolyte, directly affecting battery performance. By comparing samples modified with argon and oxygen plasma, it can be shown that the intensity of annular protrusions for oxygen plasma is higher than argon plasma [33,34]. ATR-FTIR spectroscopy was carried out to investigate each sample's functional groups. Fig. 4 a shows the ATR-FTIR spectra of unmodified and plasma modified separators by oxygen and argon plasma modification (1 min).

Plasma modified separators show a characteristic peak at 1715 cm−1 assigned to oxygen-containing functional groups (carbonyl,-c=o stretch). Argon-modified separators exhibited the same peak with lower intensity. Only energetic argon ions in argon plasma impact the separator's surface, resulting in an etching behavior. However, some excited states that remained on the surface polymer chains might be filled up with oxygen after the modification when samples are exposed to ambient air, resulting in carbonyl group formation. However, oxygen plasma directly introduced oxygen-containing functional groups such as carbonyl on the surface along with etching profile [29]. The Carbonyl peak for oxygen-modified separators is higher than that for argon-modified separators, further confirmed by XPS measurements. Fig. 4b exhibits a wide scan XPS spectra survey of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators. All spectra have intense peaks at 284.6 eV corresponding to the C1s core level, but argon and oxygen plasma modified separators exhibit new and distinct peaks at 532 eV corresponding to the O1s core level due to the formation of oxygen-containing functional groups.

The intensity of O1s peak for oxygen plasma modification is higher than that for argon plasma that attributes to a higher concentration of oxygenic groups by oxygen plasma modification. There is also a weak peak at 400 eV after argon and oxygen plasma modification corresponding to the N1s core level, which could be due to the chemical reactions between residual radicals generated by plasma and nitrogen in the air. For analytical discussion, deconvoluted XPS spectra of C1s and O1s core levels are shown in Fig. 4 for unmodified(c,f), argon(d,g), and oxygen(e,h) plasma modified separators. C1s core level was decomposed into two contributions at 285 and 286 eV corresponding to CC/CH, CC-O groups for the unmodified sample [35]. In argon plasma modified separator, CC-O peak intensified compared to the decrease in hydrocarbon content (CC/CH) peak, and another peak produced at 287.6 assigned to CO. Also, c1s core level of oxygen plasma-modified separator shows hydrocarbon content peak decreased, new peaks assigned to CO, and (C=O)-O produced at 287 and 289.1 eV, respectively, and CCO peak was intensified [35]. In the case of O1s core level, it decomposed into two parts for C=O and CO corresponding to 532.3 and 533.1 eV binding energy in unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators [35,21]. Comparing argon and oxygen plasma modified O1s deconvoluted core levels shows oxygen plasma modified sample deconvolution form of C=O and CO is different from the argon plasma modified sample. This is due to different mechanisms for producing oxygenic functional groups by argon and oxygen plasma. In oxygen plasma, O+ and O2+ions can form oxygenated functional groups with the excited states created by plasma treatment simultaneously, but in argon plasma, Oxygenated functional groups are formed on the separator's surface when the argon ions modified separator is exposed to ambient air [29]. Surface elemental composition results for plasma modifications are summarized in Table 1 . The O/C ratio for oxygen plasma modified sample is higher than that for argon plasma and unmodified separators.

The wetting properties of separators are related to contact angle measurements in Fig. 5 . For sample modified by argon plasma, the distilled water contact angle decreased from 123˚(unmodified) to 55.6˚ for 10 min plasma modification time, and electrolyte contact angle decreased from 52.5˚(unmodified) to 0˚ for 1 min plasma modification time. Also, in the case of oxygen plasma modification, distilled water contact angle decreased from 123˚ (unmodified) to 20.1˚ for 10 min plasma modification time, and electrolyte contact angle decreased from 52.5˚ (unmodified) to 0˚ for 1 min plasma modification time. These differences are due to oxygen plasma modification forming a higher concentration of oxygenic functional groups and etching profile with higher roughness confirmed in XPS, FTIR, FESEM, AFM, and Tensile strength analysis. An increase in porosity and electrolyte uptake of separator has an essential impact on battery performance from various effects like improving ionic transport and good interfacial compatibility between electrodes and separator. As shown in Table 2 , For argon plasma modification, porosity and electrolyte uptake Increased from 40.2% and 107% to 60.7% and 263%, for 0 and 10 min plasma modification time, respectively; in the case of oxygen plasma modification, the increase in porosity and electrolyte uptake was from 40.2% and 107% to 72.2% and 287%, for 0 and 10 min plasma modification time respectively. The production rate of oxygenic functional groups in oxygen plasma modified separators are more increased than in the argon plasma modified separators. Therefore, the increase in porosity and electrolyte uptake for the oxygen plasma modified sample was higher than for the argon plasma modified sample.

Surface zeta potential (SZP) analysis represents electrical properties of separator surface such as type and amount of surface charge induced by plasma modification on the separator surface. Fig. 6 a. shows SZP for unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators in 4 ramps with constant PH (PH=6). Comparison of SZP results shows oxygen plasma modified sample had a high amount of negative surface charge versus the other two samples. The average SZP for the oxygen plasma modified sample was −26.88, while this value for the argon plasma modified and unmodified separators were −25.46 and −24.62, respectively. These SZP results are related to the amount of carbonyl functional group on the separator surface, as shown in Fig. 4a and b (XPS, FTIR results). SZP analysis results enable us to use these three samples to gain insight into the increasing negative surface charge on SEI layer formation and lithium dendrite growth. To analyze electrochemical affinity between separator and electrolyte and to investigate lithium dendrite growth due to self-healing reaction between electrolyte and LiMA, LSV was carried out.

From Fig. 6b, the anodic current was observed for the unmodified separator at 4.9 V vs Li+/Li due to lithium dendrite formation by decomposition of electrolyte and oxidation of separator. However, for argon and oxygen-modified separators, oxidation potential was much higher than 5.8 V vs Li+/Li due to the presence of oxygenic functional groups with a negative charge on the surface of plasma modified separators. This is seen as the lower current density in 3.5 V potential that slowly rises until 6 V. This is due to the attractive coulombic force between the plasma modified separators' negative surface charge, and Li+ can regulate the mobility and diffusivity of lithium ions into the electrolyte. As a result, the lithium dendrite growth formation will be prevented. Therefore, the cell short circuit will be controlled. Furthermore, we can see that increasing surface charge can prevent lithium dendrite growth because the current density amount for the oxygen plasma modified sample with more negative functional groups is lower than that for the other two samples. Comparing Fig. 2 and LSV results shows that decreasing tensile strength because of plasma etching can be controlled by increasing negative surface charges. We used EIS to obtain ionic resistance (R). Fig. 6c shows Nyquist curves of unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators. The intercept of curves with z-axis in the high-frequency range represents ionic resistivity R (bulk resistance), 2.96, 2.85, and 2.73 Ω for unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators, respectively. Therefore, ionic conductivity is 0.44, 0.46, and 0.48 ms.cm−1 for unmodified and argon and oxygen plasma modified separators. The ionic conductivity of separators directly depends on the separator's thickness, porosity, electrolyte uptake, and surface charge (interaction between negative surface charge and lithium ions leads to high ionic conductivity) separators. As seen from Fig. 6c, ionic conductivity for oxygen plasma modified separators are higher than that for unmodified and argon plasma modified separators because the influence of oxygen plasma modification on porosity, electrolyte uptake, and surface charge (forming oxygenic functional groups) of separators is more than argon plasma modification. The formation of the batteries' SEI layer is more related to lithium dendrite growth [16,14]. Coulombic efficiency results correspond to lithium dendrite growth in the lithium deposition process. As a result, it clarifies the amount of SEI layer formation [4,9,16,36,37]. Decreasing average coulombic efficiency directly shows a decreasing SEI layer formation. In Fig. 6a and b coulombic efficiency curves illustrate for unmodified and plasma modified separators at 1 C capacity rate and various capacity rates from 0.1C to 2C in constant current charge-discharge mode.

As seen from Fig. 7 a, the average coulombic efficiency for unmodified, argon and oxygen plasma modified separators is 98.94%, 99.33%, and 99.73%, respectively. Comparing coulombic efficiency results with each other confirms that plasma modified separators have better average coulombic efficiency for 50 cycles. The oxygen plasma modified sample has a maximum average coulombic efficiency compared to the other samples. Improvement in coulombic efficiency can be related to the negative surface charge presence due to the carbonyl functional group in the plasma-modified separators depicted in XPS, ATR-FTIR, and Zeta potential analysis results. The negative surface charge regulates lithium-ion flux into the SEI layer. It prevents lithium dendrite growth; as a result, it lowers SEI layer formation along with SEI layer homogeneity that guarantees better cycle life and discharge capacity [14,19,22]. Furthermore, Fig. 7b depicts coulombic efficiency results at various C rates. Comparing these results clarifies increasing average coulombic efficiency for modified plasma samples; meanwhile, coulombic efficiency results for unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma modified separators are 95.51, 97.71, and 98.23, respectively. For further analysis of lithium dendrite growth in LIB structure discharge capacity results for 50 cycles at 1 C capacity rate along with discharge capacity at different C-rates are depicted in Figs. 7c and d, Fig. 6c shows decreased capacity loss for modified plasma samples; meanwhile, capacity loss for unmodified, argon, and oxygen plasma is 43.82, 36.23, and 28.57%. Improvement in capacity retention after 50 cycles can be related to regulating lithium-ion flux and lithium dendrite prevention. Discharge capacity results at different C rates are shown in Fig. 7d. After different C rates, capacity retention results for unmodified, argon, and oxygen are 7.3, 16.67, and 45.68%, respectively. Fig. 8 illustrates the mechanism of SEI layer formation and lithium dendrite growth. Comparing Fig. 8a and b, shows The hydrophobic surface of the unmodified separator without negative functional groups causes an irregular flux of lithium ions into the SEI layer in the charging process due to inhomogeneous diffusion of lithium ions into the electrolyte. Irregular lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer versus low lithium-ion diffusion in LiMA structure causes lithium ions to be deposited dendritic form in areas where the flux of lithium ions is high into the SEI layer. In the case of plasma-modified separators shown in Fig. 8b, the negative functional groups on the surface of the separators lead to the homogeneous and regulated flux of lithium ions into the SEI layer caused by electrostatic interaction between negative functional groups and Lithium ions in the charging process. This homogeneous and regulated flux of lithium ions into the SEI layer in the charging process causes the deposition of lithium ions to be homogeneous and nondendritic. On the other hand, this separator surface negativity facilitates the extraction of lithium ions from the LiMA structure due to the electrostatic interaction between lithium ions and negative functional groups in the discharge process.

In summary, it was shown that lithium-ion cells assembled with plasma modified separators have high battery performance (coulombic efficiency, discharge capacity retention) and suitable electrochemical results compare to the unmodified separator. It is demonstrated that this is due to the high negative charge on the separator surface modified with plasma. The increased negative charge lowers the lithium-ion flux in the SEI layer, resulting in decreased dendritic growth. Comparing tensile strength results with LSV results shows that decreased mechanical strength of PP separator by plasma modification can be compensated with the negative charge on the PP separator surface.
Iran Ministry of Science Research and Technology (National grants); International Affairs & Technological Exchange Center (CONNECT program).

Behnam Ghanbarzadeh: Conceptualization, Formal analysis, Visualization, Investigation, Writing – original draft, Project administration. Ali Khatibi: Conceptualization, Writing – review & editing. InfoMat
